questions.question: Which positive wave in a normal lead II ECG appears after the wave of atrial depolarization?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) R wave Explanation: R wave is the first positive wave that appears after P wave (atrial depolarization) ECG: Trace of electrical conduction of the heart. Wave Key characteristics P wave First wave to appear due to atrial depolarization (option C) Q wave First negative wave after the P wave (option B) R wave First positive wave after the P wave (option A) S wave Immediately after R wave T wave After the QRS complex (option D) U wave Ventricular myocytes with long action potentials Yellow color denotes the areas that are depolarized. Interval Duration in seconds Events of the heart PR 0.12 to 0.20 Atrioventricular conduction QRS duration 0.08 Ventricular depolarization QT 0.40 Ventricular action potential ST 0.32 Plateau portion of the ventricular action potential

questions.question: Which segment on the ECG corresponds to the period during which the ventricles remain in a state of complete depolarization?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) ST interval Explanation: ST interval corresponds to the plateau portion of the ventricular action potential, where the action potential remains in a state of sustained depolarization. Action potential (two types in heart tissues): Fast response action potential - In atrial and ventricular muscles and Purkinje fibers Slow response action potential - In nodal tissues (SA and AV nodes) Fast response action potential in ventricular muscles: The phases of action potential Corresponding ECG segment Ionic activity Key features in the phase Phase 0 The initial part of the QRS complex (Q wave) Opening of voltage I gated sodium channels The rapid myocardial influx of sodium ions. Rapid depolarization and overshoot. Phase 1 The rest of the QRS complex Closure of sodium channels Cessation of sodium influx Initial rapid repolarization Phase 2 ST segment (option B) Slow and prolonged opening of voltage I gated calcium channel Slow calcium influx Efflux of potassium Plateau phase, sustained depolarization Phase 3 T wave Cessation of calcium influx. Increased potassium efflux. Final repolarization. Phase 4 No direct representation on the ECG Opening of inward rectifying K+ channels Restoration of membrane potential Reference: GK Pal Textbook of Practical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page no 753-755 Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, Edition 26, Page 510

questions.question: Which of the following statements is false about the Class I antiarrhythmics on the cardiac action potential?

options.A: Prolong the repolarization phase by blocking potassium channels
options.B: Class Ib decrease the QT interval
options.C: Class Ic are the most potent
options.D: Reduce the rate of depolarization during phase 0

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Prolong the repolarization phase by blocking potassium channels Explanation: Class III antiarrhythmics are potassium channel blockers. Class 1 antiarrhythmics: Mechanism of action: Voltage-gated sodium channel blockers reduce the rate of depolarization during phase 0 . (option D) Class Ia Class Ib Class Ic Degree of block Moderate Mild Marked (option C) QT interval Prolong Decrease (option B) No effect Class III antiarrhythmics are potassium channel blockers, which decrease potassium efflux out of the cardiac cells and prolong the QTc interval.

questions.question: Which among the following options primarily contributes to QT prolongation on the ECG?

options.A: Opening of inward rectifying K+ channels in phase 4

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Delayed repolarization during Phase 2 or 3 Explanation: QT prolongation on ECG is primarily caused by delayed repolarization during Phase 2 and 3 of the cardiac action potential. The Corresponding ECG segment Ionic activity Key features in the phase Phase 0 The initial part of the QRS complex (Q wave) Opening of voltage I gated sodium channels A rapid myocardial influx of sodium ions. (option D) Rapid depolarization and overshoot. Phase 1 The rest of the QRS complex Closure of sodium channels Cessation of sodium influx Initial rapid repolarization Phase 2 ST segment (option C) Slow and prolonged opening of voltage I gated calcium channel Slow calcium influx Efflux of potassium Plateau phase, sustained depolarization Phase 3 T wave (option C) Cessation of calcium influx. Increased potassium efflux. Final repolarization. Phase 4 No direct representation on the ECG Opening of inward rectifying K+ channels (option A) Restoration of membrane potential Class III antiarrhythmic drugs are potassium channel blockers that decrease potassium efflux out of the cell and prolong the QT interval. Reference: GK Pal Textbook of Practical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 753-755 Ganong's Review of Medical Physiology, Edition 26, Page 510, 511 www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK482322/

questions.question: If the voltage in Lead II of the Einthoven triangle is 1.5 mV and the voltage in Lead III is 0.5 mV, what is the voltage in Lead I?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) 1.0 mV Explanation: Voltages of lead I + lead III = lead II (Einthoven law) Hence, from the question, Lead I + 0.5 mV = 1.5 mV Lead I = 1.5 mV - 0.5 mV Lead II = 1.0 mV Einthoven triangle: It is an equilateral triangle and each side represents the axis of one of the bipolar limb leads. It is shaped like an inverted triangle, with the base between two shoulders and the apex pointing toward the groin. The heart is considered to be at the center of the Einthoven triangle. Each corner of the triangle is the location for an electrode for two leads to record ECG. Consequently, the three limbs of the triangle represent three leads. Einthoven law: Voltages of lead I + lead III = lead II Voltage calculation: Voltage recorded in each lead as follows Lead I: left arm - right arm Lead II: Left foot - right arm Lead III: Left foot- left arm

questions.question: Which of the following statements is true regarding ECG leads?

options.A: Chest leads are bipolar limb leads- horizontal plane.
options.B: Positive end of the voltmeter is connected to the Wilson terminal.
options.C: In lead II the negative end is the right arm

questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) In lead II the negative end is the right arm Explanation: In lead II the negative end is right arm and the positive end is left foot. ECG Leads: An ECG lead is a pair of electrodes used to detect the potential differences of the heart. Leads in a standard 12-lead ECG: Leads Number of Leads Bipolar limb leads Lead I, Lead II, Lead III Augmented unipolar limb leads (option D) aVR, aVL, aVF Precordial/ chest unipolar leads V1, V2, V3, V4, V5 ,V6 Bipolar Unipolar Both the electrodes are active It is the difference between positive - negative Located on the frontal/ coronal plane. (option A) One electrode is the active or recording electrode and the other one is the indifferent electrode. There are six unipolar chest leads and three unipolar limb leads( augmented limb leads) Located on the frontal/ coronal plane .(option A) Bipolar limb leads: Leads Voltmeter connection Volage vector direction Negative end Positive end Lead I Right arm Left arm Negative to positive Lead II Right arm (option C) Left foot Negative to positive Lead III Left arm Left foot Positive to negative Chest leads: Unipolar, located on the horizontal plane. Exploring electrodes on the chest surface and indifferent electrodes are connected to the right arm, left arm and left leg through the high resistance, which is called Wilson’s terminal. (option B) Leads Position V1 4th intercostal space, right sternal border V2 4th intercostal space, left sternal border V3 Midway between V2 and V4 V4 5th intercostal space, midclavicular line V5 5th intercostal space, anterior axillary line V6 5th intercostal space, midaxillary line

questions.question: According to hexaxial reference system of ECG, the direction of voltage vector of lead aVR is:
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) -150 ° Explanation: The positive of lead aVR is at -150 ° and the negative of aVR is at +30 ° The axes of augmented limb leads are interspersed between bipolar limb leads as shown as in the picture. This is known as the Hexaxial system. Augmented limb leads: Lead Positive Electrode Negative Electrodes View Clinical Use aVR Right Arm (RA) Left Arm (LA) + Left Leg (LL) From the right shoulder Right-sided heart abnormalities aVL Left Arm (LA) Right Arm (RA) + Left Leg (LL) From the left shoulder Left-sided heart abnormalities aVF Left Leg (LL) Right Arm (RA) + Left Arm (LA) From the inferior (foot) position Inferior heart abnormalities Vector of augmented limb lead = 3/2 vector of unaugmented limb lead Reference: GK Pal Textbook of Practical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 761, 766, 770. Guyton & Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, Edition 14, Page 140, 141, 143, 144.

questions.question: In a patient presenting with ST elevation in leads V1 and V2 on an ECG, which of the following is the most likely diagnosis and the corresponding coronary artery involved?

options.A: Anterior wall myocardial infarction due to Right Coronary Artery (RCA) occlusion.
options.B: Inferior wall myocardial infarction due to Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery occlusion.
options.C: Septal wall myocardial infarction due to Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery occlusion.
options.D: Lateral wall myocardial infarction due to Left Circumflex (LCX) artery occlusion.

questions.explanation: occlusion. Correct Answer: C) Septal wall myocardial infarction due to Left Anterior Descending (LAD) artery occlusion. Explanation: Leads V1 and V2: ST elevation in these leads is indicative of damage to the septal wall of the left ventricle. Left Anterior Descending (LAD) Artery: The LAD artery supplies the anterior and septal walls of the left ventricle. Therefore, ST elevation in V1 and V2, which view the septal wall, is typically associated with LAD artery occlusion. ST Elevation Location Affected Cardiac Wall Coronary Artery I, aVL, V5, V6 Lateral Wall of the Left Ventricle Left Circumflex (LCX) or Left Anterior Descending (LAD) II, III, aVF Inferior Wall of the Left Ventricle Right Coronary Artery (RCA) V1, V2 Septal Wall of the Left Ventricle Left Anterior Descending (LAD) V3, V4 Anterior Wall of the Left Ventricle Left Anterior Descending (LAD) V1 to V4 Anterior Wall including Septal Left Anterior Descending (LAD) V7, V8, V9 Posterior Wall of the Left Ventricle Right Coronary Artery (RCA) or Left Circumflex (LCX) ST elevation in leads V1 and V2 is not associated with the anterior wall but with the septal wall. RCA occlusion is more likely to cause inferior wall damage ( Option A) Although LAD artery occlusion is involved, V1 and V2 are indicative of septal, not inferior, wall damage. Inferior wall damage is associated with leads II, III, and aVF ( Option B) Lateral wall myocardial infarction is associated with ST elevation in leads I, aVL, V5, and V6, not V1 and V2. LCX occlusion is involved in lateral wall damage ( Option D) Reference: www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK537228/ www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK553168/ www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK540996/ www.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/books/NBK562234/#:~:text=Anterior%20wall%20myocardial%20infarction%20 pubmed.ncbi.nlm.nih.gov/29262146/#:~:text=Inferior%20wall%20myocardial%20infarction%20

questions.question: If a T wave spans 4 small boxes and 3 vertical boxes on an ECG recording paper moving at a standard speed of 25 mm/second,with standard voltage calibration, what is the duration and amplitude of the T wave?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: A) Duration: 0.16 seconds, Amplitude: 0.3 mV Explanation: Duration Calculation: Each small box on the ECG paper represents 0.04 seconds. If the T wave spans 4 small boxes, the duration of the T wave is: 4 x 0.04= 0.16 sec Amplitude Calculation: Each small box represents 0.1 mV. If the T wave spans 3 small boxes in height, the amplitude is: 3 x 0.1 = 0.3 mV Paper Speed: The standard paper speed is 25 mm/second. This means that the ECG paper moves at a rate of 25 millimeters per second. Measurement for Duration: The ECG paper is divided into small and large boxes. Each large box is 5 mm x 5 mm, and each small box within a large box is 1 mm x 1 mm. 1 Large Box: Represents 0.20 seconds (200 milliseconds). 1 Small Box: Represents 0.04 seconds (40 milliseconds) Amplitude: The amplitude of the ECG waveforms is measured in millivolts (mV). Each vertical small box represents 0.1 mV. Each large box represents 0.5 mV (since it contains 5 small boxes). Although the duration is correct, the amplitude given is for a different number of boxes ( Option B) The duration calculation is correct, but the amplitude is not accurate for the given number of boxes ( Option C) The amplitude is correct, but the duration provided is for a different number of boxes ( Option D) Reference: Guyton & Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, Edition 14, Page 137

questions.question: Which of the following can be considered as Left axis deviation?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: B) -60° Explanation: Left axis deviation falls between -90° to -30° The normal cardiac axis value- Normal axis deviation: -30° to +110° Left axis deviation: -90° to -30° Right axis deviation: +110° to +180° Methods to calculate the mean cardiac axis- Quadrant Method : The simplest method that uses leads I and aVF. Determine the net deflection (positive or negative) of the QRS complex in Lead I and aVF. Place the axis in the appropriate quadrant based on the signs: Lead I (+) and aVF (+): Normal axis Lead I (-) and aVF (+): Right axis deviation Lead I (-) and aVF (-): Extreme right axis deviation Lead I (+) and aVF (-): Left axis deviation Einthoven Triangle Method: Uses the net deflections in Leads I, II, and III to calculate the axis. Calculate the net QRS deflection for each of the three limb leads. Use vector addition to combine these deflections. Calculate the resultant vector and determine its angle. Graphical Method: Involves plotting the QRS vectors on a graph to find the axis. Measure the net deflection of the QRS complex in at least two leads. Plot these values on a coordinate system. Use vector addition to determine the overall direction of the QRS vector. Inspection of the Isoelectric Lead with Hexaxial system: Identifies the isoelectric lead (lead with the smallest net QRS deflection). Find the lead with the most isoelectric QRS complex. The QRS axis is perpendicular to this lead. Use adjacent leads to refine the exact axis using hexaxial system. Reference: Guyton & Hall Textbook of Medical Physiology, Edition 14, Page 148,149 GK Pal Textbook of Practical Physiology, 1st Edition, Page 769,770

questions.question: In the His bundle electrogram (HBE), what does the H wave denote?
questions.explanation: Correct Answer: C) Depolarization of the His bundle Explanation: H wave in His bundle electrogram represents the depolarization of the His bundle His Bundle Electrogram (HBE): Invasive ECG procedure A catheter containing an electrode at its tip is inserted through an arm vein into the right atrium close to the tricuspid valve. The electrode records the HBE. Waveforms in the His Bundle Electrogram A Wave (Option A) The A wave represents atrial depolarization. H Wave (Option C) The H wave represents depolarization of the His bundle’s upper part. V Wave: (Option B) The V wave represents ventricular depolarization. Intervals in the His Bundle Electrogram P-A Interval The PA interval is the time from the onset of the P wave on the surface ECG to the onset of the A wave on the His bundle electrogram. The PA interval typically ranges from 25 to 55 milliseconds. A-H Interval The A-H interval is the time between the onset of the A wave and the onset of the H wave. Typically ranges from 50 to 120 milliseconds. This interval represents conduction time through the AV node. A prolonged A-H interval suggests AV nodal conduction delay. H-V Interval Typically ranges from 35 to 55 milliseconds. This interval represents conduction time through the His-Purkinje system. A prolonged H-V interval suggests an infranodal conduction delay or block.
